summary: This is an email chain from September 2019 discussing the taint review process for electronic materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence. The correspondence involves prosecutors and investigators questioning the low volume of documents (20,000) extracted from a large number of seized devices and seeking status updates on the review.

persons.name: Ori
persons.context: Appears to be a prosecutor or attorney involved in the Epstein case, sending and receiving emails about the status of the taint review of seized materials and coordinating with other parties.

persons.name: Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein is the subject of the investigation; materials were seized from his Manhattan residence, and his attorney provided search terms for the taint review.

connections.description: Ori is a prosecutor or attorney involved in the legal case against Jeffrey Epstein, coordinating the taint review of evidence seized from Epstein's residence.

events.title: Materials made available from seizure
events.description: Materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence were made available for review by investigators.

events.title: Email inquiry about document volume
events.description: An email questions why only 20,000 documents were extracted from approximately 38 computers/electronic storage devices and 55 CDs seized from Epstein's residence, seeking clarification.

locations: New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Approximately 38 computers and/or electronic storage devices and 55 CDs were seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence.
Only about 20,000 documents were initially reported from the seized devices, with many being non-user files like Adobe instructions.
A taint review was being conducted on the seized materials, with Epstein's attorney providing search terms to segregate privileged documents.
Prosecutors were seeking status updates on the taint review process, indicating ongoing investigation and evidence processing in September 2019.
